trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure Security and Audit Log Management | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure Security and Audit Log Management | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Article provides an introduction for generating, collecting, and analyzing security logs from services hosted on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Article provides an introduction for generating, collecting, and analyzing security logs from services hosted on Azure.

trans-unit.source: It is intended for IT professionals and security analysts who deal with information asset management on a daily basis, including those responsible for their organization's security and compliance efforts.
trans-unit.target: It is intended for IT professionals and security analysts who deal with information asset management on a daily basis, including those responsible for their organization's security and compliance efforts.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure security and audit log management
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure security and audit log management

trans-unit.source: Azure enables customers to perform security event generation and collection from Azure Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) and Platform as a Service (PaaS) roles to central storage in their subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: Azure enables customers to perform security event generation and collection from Azure Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) and Platform as a Service (PaaS) roles to central storage in their subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Customers can then use [HDInsight](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/services/hdinsight/) to aggregate and analyze the collected events.
trans-unit.target: Customers can then use [HDInsight](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/services/hdinsight/) to aggregate and analyze the collected events.

trans-unit.source: In addition, these collected events can be exported to on-premises security information and event management (SIEM) systems for ongoing monitoring.
trans-unit.target: In addition, these collected events can be exported to on-premises security information and event management (SIEM) systems for ongoing monitoring.

trans-unit.source: The Azure security logging, analysis, and monitoring lifecycle includes:
trans-unit.target: The Azure security logging, analysis, and monitoring lifecycle includes:

trans-unit.source: **Generation**: Instrument applications and the infrastructure to raise events
trans-unit.target: **Generation**: Instrument applications and the infrastructure to raise events

trans-unit.source: **Collection**: Configure Azure to collect the various security logs in a storage account
trans-unit.target: **Collection**: Configure Azure to collect the various security logs in a storage account

trans-unit.source: **Analysis**: Use Azure tools such as HDInsight and on-premises SIEM systems to analyze the logs and generate security insights
trans-unit.target: **Analysis**: Use Azure tools such as HDInsight and on-premises SIEM systems to analyze the logs and generate security insights

trans-unit.source: **Monitoring and reporting**: Azure offers centralized monitoring and analysis systems that provide continuous visibility and timely alerts
trans-unit.target: **Monitoring and reporting**: Azure offers centralized monitoring and analysis systems that provide continuous visibility and timely alerts

trans-unit.source: This article focuses on the generation and collection phases of the lifecycle.
trans-unit.target: This article focuses on the generation and collection phases of the lifecycle.

trans-unit.source: Log generation
trans-unit.target: Log generation

trans-unit.source: Security events are raised in the Windows Event Log for the **System**, **Security**, and **Application** channels in virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: Security events are raised in the Windows Event Log for the **System**, **Security**, and **Application** channels in virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: To ensure that events are logged without potential data loss, it is important to appropriately configure the size of the event log.
trans-unit.target: To ensure that events are logged without potential data loss, it is important to appropriately configure the size of the event log.

trans-unit.source: Base the size of the event log on the number of events that auditing policy settings generate and the event collection policies defined.
trans-unit.target: Base the size of the event log on the number of events that auditing policy settings generate and the event collection policies defined.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Planning for security audit monitoring and management](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/ee513968.aspx#BKMK_4).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Planning for security audit monitoring and management](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/ee513968.aspx#BKMK_4).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] When using Windows Event Forwarding (WEF) or Azure Diagnostics (explained in the [Log Collection](#log-collection) section) to pull logs from Cloud Services or virtual machines, consider the potential impact of system outages.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] When using Windows Event Forwarding (WEF) or Azure Diagnostics (explained in the [Log Collection](#log-collection) section) to pull logs from Cloud Services or virtual machines, consider the potential impact of system outages.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your WEF environment goes down for some time, you either need to make sure the log size is big enough to account for a longer time duration or be prepared for possible log data loss.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your WEF environment goes down for some time, you either need to make sure the log size is big enough to account for a longer time duration or be prepared for possible log data loss.

trans-unit.source: For Cloud Services applications that are deployed in Azure and virtual machines created from the [Azure Virtual Machines Marketplace](http://azure.microsoft.com/marketplace/virtual-machines/#microsoft), a set of operating system security events are enabled by default.
trans-unit.target: For Cloud Services applications that are deployed in Azure and virtual machines created from the [Azure Virtual Machines Marketplace](http://azure.microsoft.com/marketplace/virtual-machines/#microsoft), a set of operating system security events are enabled by default.

trans-unit.source: Customers can add, remove, or modify events to be audited by customizing the operating system audit policy.
trans-unit.target: Customers can add, remove, or modify events to be audited by customizing the operating system audit policy.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Security Policy Settings Reference](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj852210.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Security Policy Settings Reference](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj852210.aspx).

trans-unit.source: You can use the following methods to generate additional logs from operating system (such as audit policy changes) and Windows components (such as IIS):
trans-unit.target: You can use the following methods to generate additional logs from operating system (such as audit policy changes) and Windows components (such as IIS):

trans-unit.source: Group Policy to roll out policy settings for virtual machines in Azure that are domain-joined
trans-unit.target: Group Policy to roll out policy settings for virtual machines in Azure that are domain-joined

trans-unit.source: Desired State Configuration (DSC) to push and manage policy settings.
trans-unit.target: Desired State Configuration (DSC) to push and manage policy settings.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Azure PowerShell DSC](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/powershell/archive/2014/08/07/introducing-the-azure-powershell-dsc-desired-state-configuration-extension.aspx)
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Azure PowerShell DSC](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/powershell/archive/2014/08/07/introducing-the-azure-powershell-dsc-desired-state-configuration-extension.aspx)

trans-unit.source: Service Deployment role startup code to roll out settings for Cloud Services (PaaS scenario)
trans-unit.target: Service Deployment role startup code to roll out settings for Cloud Services (PaaS scenario)

trans-unit.source: Configuring Azure role startup tasks enables code to run before a role starts.
trans-unit.target: Configuring Azure role startup tasks enables code to run before a role starts.

trans-unit.source: You can define a startup task for a role by adding the **Startup** element to the definition of the role in the service definition file, as shown in the following example.
trans-unit.target: You can define a startup task for a role by adding the **Startup** element to the definition of the role in the service definition file, as shown in the following example.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Run Startup Tasks in Azure](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/hh180155.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Run Startup Tasks in Azure](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/hh180155.aspx).

trans-unit.source: The task file that is to be run as a Startup task (EnableLogOnAudit.cmd in the following example) needs to be included in your build package.
trans-unit.target: The task file that is to be run as a Startup task (EnableLogOnAudit.cmd in the following example) needs to be included in your build package.

trans-unit.source: If you are using Visual Studio, add the file to your cloud project, right-click the file name, click **Properties**, and then set **Copy to output Directory** to **Copy always**.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Visual Studio, add the file to your cloud project, right-click the file name, click **Properties**, and then set **Copy to output Directory** to **Copy always**.

trans-unit.source: Contents of EnableLogOnAudit.cmd:
trans-unit.target: Contents of EnableLogOnAudit.cmd:

trans-unit.source: [Auditpol.exe](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc731451.aspx) used in the previous example is a command-line tool included in Windows Server operating system that allows you to manage audit policy settings.
trans-unit.target: [Auditpol.exe](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc731451.aspx) used in the previous example is a command-line tool included in Windows Server operating system that allows you to manage audit policy settings.

trans-unit.source: In addition to generating Windows event logs, various Windows operating system components can be configured to generate logs that are important for security analysis and monitoring.
trans-unit.target: In addition to generating Windows event logs, various Windows operating system components can be configured to generate logs that are important for security analysis and monitoring.

trans-unit.source: For example, Internet Information Services (IIS) logs and http.err logs are automatically generated for web roles, and they can be configured for collection.
trans-unit.target: For example, Internet Information Services (IIS) logs and http.err logs are automatically generated for web roles, and they can be configured for collection.

trans-unit.source: These logs provide valuable information that can be used to identify unauthorized access or attacks against your web role.
trans-unit.target: These logs provide valuable information that can be used to identify unauthorized access or attacks against your web role.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Configure Logging in IIS](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh831775.aspx) and [Advanced Logging for IIS – Custom Logging](http://www.iis.net/learn/extensions/advanced-logging-module/advanced-logging-for-iis-custom-logging).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Configure Logging in IIS](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh831775.aspx) and [Advanced Logging for IIS – Custom Logging](http://www.iis.net/learn/extensions/advanced-logging-module/advanced-logging-for-iis-custom-logging).

trans-unit.source: To change IIS logging in a web role, customers can add a startup task to the web role service definition file.
trans-unit.target: To change IIS logging in a web role, customers can add a startup task to the web role service definition file.

trans-unit.source: The following example enables HTTP logging for a website named Contoso, and it specifies that IIS should log all requests for the Contoso website.
trans-unit.target: The following example enables HTTP logging for a website named Contoso, and it specifies that IIS should log all requests for the Contoso website.

trans-unit.source: The task that updates the IIS configuration needs to be included within the service definition file of the web role.
trans-unit.target: The task that updates the IIS configuration needs to be included within the service definition file of the web role.

trans-unit.source: The following changes to the service definition file runs a startup task that configures IIS logging by running a script called ConfigureIISLogging.cmd.
trans-unit.target: The following changes to the service definition file runs a startup task that configures IIS logging by running a script called ConfigureIISLogging.cmd.

trans-unit.source: Contents of ConfigureIISLogging:cmd
trans-unit.target: Contents of ConfigureIISLogging:cmd

trans-unit.source: Log collection
trans-unit.target: Log collection

trans-unit.source: Collection of security events and logs from Cloud Services or virtual machines in Azure occurs through two primary methods:
trans-unit.target: Collection of security events and logs from Cloud Services or virtual machines in Azure occurs through two primary methods:

trans-unit.source: Azure Diagnostics, collects events in a customer’s Azure storage account
trans-unit.target: Azure Diagnostics, collects events in a customer’s Azure storage account

trans-unit.source: Windows Event Forwarding (WEF), a technology in computers running Windows
trans-unit.target: Windows Event Forwarding (WEF), a technology in computers running Windows

trans-unit.source: Some key differences between these two technologies are included in the table below.
trans-unit.target: Some key differences between these two technologies are included in the table below.

trans-unit.source: Based on your requirements and these key differences, the appropriate method needs to be chosen to implement log collection.
trans-unit.target: Based on your requirements and these key differences, the appropriate method needs to be chosen to implement log collection.

trans-unit.source: Azure Diagnostics
trans-unit.target: Azure Diagnostics

trans-unit.source: Windows Event Forwarding
trans-unit.target: Windows Event Forwarding

trans-unit.source: Supports Azure Virtual Machines and Azure Cloud Services
trans-unit.target: Supports Azure Virtual Machines and Azure Cloud Services

trans-unit.source: Supports domain-joined Azure Virtual Machines only
trans-unit.target: Supports domain-joined Azure Virtual Machines only

trans-unit.source: Supports a variety of log formats, such as Windows event logs, [Event Tracing for Windows](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/bb968803.aspx) (ETW) traces, and IIS logs.
trans-unit.target: Supports a variety of log formats, such as Windows event logs, [Event Tracing for Windows](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/bb968803.aspx) (ETW) traces, and IIS logs.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Azure Diagnostics supported data sources](#diagnostics)
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Azure Diagnostics supported data sources](#diagnostics)

trans-unit.source: Supports Windows event logs only
trans-unit.target: Supports Windows event logs only

trans-unit.source: Pushes collected data to Azure Storage
trans-unit.target: Pushes collected data to Azure Storage

trans-unit.source: Moves collected data to central collector servers
trans-unit.target: Moves collected data to central collector servers

trans-unit.source: Security event data collection with Windows Event Forwarding
trans-unit.target: Security event data collection with Windows Event Forwarding

trans-unit.source: For domain-joined Azure Virtual Machines, you can configure WEF by using Group Policy settings in the same manner as for on-premises domain-joined computers.
trans-unit.target: For domain-joined Azure Virtual Machines, you can configure WEF by using Group Policy settings in the same manner as for on-premises domain-joined computers.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Hybrid Cloud](http://www.microsoft.com/server-cloud/solutions/hybrid-cloud.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Hybrid Cloud](http://www.microsoft.com/server-cloud/solutions/hybrid-cloud.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Using this approach, an organization could purchase an IaaS subscription, connect it to their corporate network by using [ExpressRoute](http://azure.microsoft.com/services/expressroute/) or site-to-site VPN, and then join the virtual machines that you have in Azure to the corporate domain.
trans-unit.target: Using this approach, an organization could purchase an IaaS subscription, connect it to their corporate network by using [ExpressRoute](http://azure.microsoft.com/services/expressroute/) or site-to-site VPN, and then join the virtual machines that you have in Azure to the corporate domain.

trans-unit.source: Afterwards, you can configure WEF from the domain-joined machines.
trans-unit.target: Afterwards, you can configure WEF from the domain-joined machines.

trans-unit.source: Event forwarding is broken into two parts: the source and the collector.
trans-unit.target: Event forwarding is broken into two parts: the source and the collector.

trans-unit.source: The source is the computer in which the security logs are generated.
trans-unit.target: The source is the computer in which the security logs are generated.

trans-unit.source: The collector is the centralized server that collects and consolidates the event logs.
trans-unit.target: The collector is the centralized server that collects and consolidates the event logs.

trans-unit.source: IT administrators can subscribe to events so that they can receive and store events that are forwarded from remote computers (the event source).
trans-unit.target: IT administrators can subscribe to events so that they can receive and store events that are forwarded from remote computers (the event source).

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Configure Computers to Forward and Collect Events](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc748890.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Configure Computers to Forward and Collect Events](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc748890.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Collected Windows events can be sent to on-premises analysis tools, such as a SIEM, for further analysis.
trans-unit.target: Collected Windows events can be sent to on-premises analysis tools, such as a SIEM, for further analysis.

trans-unit.source: Security data collection with Azure Diagnostics
trans-unit.target: Security data collection with Azure Diagnostics

trans-unit.source: Azure Diagnostics enables you to collect diagnostic data from a cloud service worker role or web role, or from virtual machines running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Azure Diagnostics enables you to collect diagnostic data from a cloud service worker role or web role, or from virtual machines running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: It is a predefined guest agent extension that needs to be enabled and configured for data collection.
trans-unit.target: It is a predefined guest agent extension that needs to be enabled and configured for data collection.

trans-unit.source: A customer's subscription can include pushing the data to Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: A customer's subscription can include pushing the data to Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: The data is encrypted in-transit (by using HTTPS).
trans-unit.target: The data is encrypted in-transit (by using HTTPS).

trans-unit.source: The examples provided in this document are using Azure Diagnostics 1.2.
trans-unit.target: The examples provided in this document are using Azure Diagnostics 1.2.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you upgrade to version 1.2 or higher for security data collection.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you upgrade to version 1.2 or higher for security data collection.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Collect Logging Data by Using Azure Diagnostics](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/gg433048.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Collect Logging Data by Using Azure Diagnostics](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/gg433048.aspx).

trans-unit.source: The following diagram shows a high-level data flow for security data collection that uses Azure Diagnostics and further analysis and monitoring.
trans-unit.target: The following diagram shows a high-level data flow for security data collection that uses Azure Diagnostics and further analysis and monitoring.

trans-unit.source: Azure Diagnostics moves logs from customer Cloud Services applications and [Azure Virtual Machines](virtual-machines-about.md) to Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Azure Diagnostics moves logs from customer Cloud Services applications and [Azure Virtual Machines](virtual-machines-about.md) to Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: Based on a log format, some data is stored in Azure tables and some in blobs.
trans-unit.target: Based on a log format, some data is stored in Azure tables and some in blobs.

trans-unit.source: Data that is collected in [Azure Storage](storage-introduction.md) can be downloaded to on-premises SIEM systems by using Azure Storage client library for monitoring and analysis.
trans-unit.target: Data that is collected in [Azure Storage](storage-introduction.md) can be downloaded to on-premises SIEM systems by using Azure Storage client library for monitoring and analysis.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, HDInsight can be used for further analysis of the data in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, HDInsight can be used for further analysis of the data in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Following are some examples of security data collection that use Azure Diagnostics.
trans-unit.target: Following are some examples of security data collection that use Azure Diagnostics.

trans-unit.source: Security data collection from Azure Virtual Machines by using Azure Diagnostics
trans-unit.target: Security data collection from Azure Virtual Machines by using Azure Diagnostics

trans-unit.source: The following examples use Azure Diagnostics 1.2 and Azure PowerShell cmdlets to enable security data collection from virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: The following examples use Azure Diagnostics 1.2 and Azure PowerShell cmdlets to enable security data collection from virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: The data is collected from virtual machines on a scheduled interval (that is configurable) and pushed to Azure Storage within a customer’s subscription.
trans-unit.target: The data is collected from virtual machines on a scheduled interval (that is configurable) and pushed to Azure Storage within a customer’s subscription.

trans-unit.source: In this section, we will walk through two log collection scenarios using Azure Diagnostics:
trans-unit.target: In this section, we will walk through two log collection scenarios using Azure Diagnostics:

trans-unit.source: Set up a new instance of a security log collection pipeline on a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Set up a new instance of a security log collection pipeline on a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Update an existing security log collection pipeline with a new configuration on a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Update an existing security log collection pipeline with a new configuration on a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Set up a new instance of a security log collection pipeline on a virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Set up a new instance of a security log collection pipeline on a virtual machine

trans-unit.source: In this example, we set up a new instance of a security log collection pipeline that uses Azure Diagnostics, and we detect logon failure events (event IDs 4624 and 4625) from the virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we set up a new instance of a security log collection pipeline that uses Azure Diagnostics, and we detect logon failure events (event IDs 4624 and 4625) from the virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: You can implement the following steps from your development environment, or you can use a Remote Desktop session through Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) to the node in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: You can implement the following steps from your development environment, or you can use a Remote Desktop session through Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) to the node in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Install the Azure PowerShell SDK
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Install the Azure PowerShell SDK

trans-unit.source: The Azure PowerShell SDK provides cmdlets to configure Azure Diagnostics on Azure Virtual Machines.
trans-unit.target: The Azure PowerShell SDK provides cmdlets to configure Azure Diagnostics on Azure Virtual Machines.

trans-unit.source: The necessary cmdlets are available in Azure PowerShell version 0.8.7 or later.
trans-unit.target: The necessary cmdlets are available in Azure PowerShell version 0.8.7 or later.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](powershell-install-configure.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](powershell-install-configure.md).

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Prepare the configuration file
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Prepare the configuration file

trans-unit.source: Prepare the configuration file based on the events you would like to collect.
trans-unit.target: Prepare the configuration file based on the events you would like to collect.

trans-unit.source: Following is an example of an Azure Diagnostics configuration file to collect Windows events from the **Security** channel, with filters added to collect only logon success and failure events.
trans-unit.target: Following is an example of an Azure Diagnostics configuration file to collect Windows events from the **Security** channel, with filters added to collect only logon success and failure events.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Azure Diagnostics 1.2 Configuration Schema](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn782207.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Azure Diagnostics 1.2 Configuration Schema](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn782207.aspx).

trans-unit.source: The storage account can be specified in the configuration file, or it can be specified as a parameter when you run the Azure PowerShell cmdlets to set up Azure Diagnostics.
trans-unit.target: The storage account can be specified in the configuration file, or it can be specified as a parameter when you run the Azure PowerShell cmdlets to set up Azure Diagnostics.

trans-unit.source: When you save the previous contents as an XML file, set the encoding to **UTF-8**.
trans-unit.target: When you save the previous contents as an XML file, set the encoding to **UTF-8**.

trans-unit.source: If you are using Notepad, you'll see the encoding option available in the "Save As" dialog box.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Notepad, you'll see the encoding option available in the "Save As" dialog box.

trans-unit.source: The table below lists some key attributes to note in the configuration file.
trans-unit.target: The table below lists some key attributes to note in the configuration file.

trans-unit.source: Attribute
trans-unit.target: Attribute

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: overallQuotaInMB
trans-unit.target: overallQuotaInMB

trans-unit.source: The maximum amount of local disk space that can be consumed by Azure Diagnostics (value is configurable).
trans-unit.target: The maximum amount of local disk space that can be consumed by Azure Diagnostics (value is configurable).

trans-unit.source: scheduledTransferPeriod
trans-unit.target: scheduledTransferPeriod

trans-unit.source: The interval between scheduled transfers to Azure Storage, rounded up to the nearest minute.
trans-unit.target: The interval between scheduled transfers to Azure Storage, rounded up to the nearest minute.

trans-unit.source: Name
trans-unit.target: Name

trans-unit.source: In WindowsEventLog, this attibute is the XPath query that describes the Windows events to be collected.
trans-unit.target: In WindowsEventLog, this attibute is the XPath query that describes the Windows events to be collected.

trans-unit.source: You can filter the data collection by adding a filter such as Event ID, Provider Name, or Channel.
trans-unit.target: You can filter the data collection by adding a filter such as Event ID, Provider Name, or Channel.

trans-unit.source: All Windows Event log data is moved to a table named **WADWindowsEventLogsTable**.
trans-unit.target: All Windows Event log data is moved to a table named **WADWindowsEventLogsTable**.

trans-unit.source: Currently, Azure Diagnostics does not support renaming the table.
trans-unit.target: Currently, Azure Diagnostics does not support renaming the table.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Validate configuration XML file
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Validate configuration XML file

trans-unit.source: Use the following procedure to validate that there is no error in the configuration XML file, and that it is compatible with the Azure Diagnostic schema:
trans-unit.target: Use the following procedure to validate that there is no error in the configuration XML file, and that it is compatible with the Azure Diagnostic schema:

trans-unit.source: To download the schema file, run the following command, and then save the file.
trans-unit.target: To download the schema file, run the following command, and then save the file.

trans-unit.source: (Get-AzureServiceAvailableExtension -ExtensionName 'PaaSDiagnostics' -ProviderNamespace 'Microsoft.Azure.Diagnostics').PublicConfigurationSchema | Out-File -Encoding utf8 -FilePath 'WadConfigSchema.xsd'
trans-unit.target: (Get-AzureServiceAvailableExtension -ExtensionName 'PaaSDiagnostics' -ProviderNamespace 'Microsoft.Azure.Diagnostics').PublicConfigurationSchema | Out-File -Encoding utf8 -FilePath 'WadConfigSchema.xsd'

trans-unit.source: After you download the schema file, you can validate the configuration XML file against the schema.
trans-unit.target: After you download the schema file, you can validate the configuration XML file against the schema.

trans-unit.source: To validate the file by using Visual Studio:
trans-unit.target: To validate the file by using Visual Studio:

trans-unit.source: Open the XML file in Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Open the XML file in Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Press F4 to open **Properties**
trans-unit.target: Press F4 to open **Properties**

trans-unit.source: Click **Schema**, click **Add**, select the schema file that you downloaded (WadConfigSchema.XSD), and then click **OK**
trans-unit.target: Click **Schema**, click **Add**, select the schema file that you downloaded (WadConfigSchema.XSD), and then click **OK**

trans-unit.source: On the **View** menu, click **Error List** to see if there are any validation errors.
trans-unit.target: On the **View** menu, click **Error List** to see if there are any validation errors.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Configure Azure Diagnostics
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Configure Azure Diagnostics

trans-unit.source: Use the following steps to enable Azure Diagnostics and start the data collection:
trans-unit.target: Use the following steps to enable Azure Diagnostics and start the data collection:

trans-unit.source: To open Azure PowerShell, type **Add-AzureAccount**, and press ENTER.
trans-unit.target: To open Azure PowerShell, type **Add-AzureAccount**, and press ENTER.

trans-unit.source: Sign in with your Azure account.
trans-unit.target: Sign in with your Azure account.

trans-unit.source: Run the following PowerShell script.
trans-unit.target: Run the following PowerShell script.

trans-unit.source: Make sure to update the storage_name, key, config_path, service_name, and vm_name.
trans-unit.target: Make sure to update the storage_name, key, config_path, service_name, and vm_name.

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Generate events
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Generate events

trans-unit.source: For demonstration purposes, we will create some logon events and verify that data is flowing to Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: For demonstration purposes, we will create some logon events and verify that data is flowing to Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: As shown previously in Step 2, the XML file is configured to collect Event ID 4624 (Logon Success) and Event ID 4625 (Logon Failure) from the **Security** channel.
trans-unit.target: As shown previously in Step 2, the XML file is configured to collect Event ID 4624 (Logon Success) and Event ID 4625 (Logon Failure) from the **Security** channel.

trans-unit.source: To generate these events:
trans-unit.target: To generate these events:

trans-unit.source: Open an RDP session to your virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Open an RDP session to your virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Enter incorrect credentials to generate some failed logon events (Event ID 4625).
trans-unit.target: Enter incorrect credentials to generate some failed logon events (Event ID 4625).

trans-unit.source: After a few failed logon attempts, enter the correct credentials to generate a successful logon event (EventID 4624).
trans-unit.target: After a few failed logon attempts, enter the correct credentials to generate a successful logon event (EventID 4624).

trans-unit.source: Step 6: View data
trans-unit.target: Step 6: View data

trans-unit.source: About five minutes after you complete the previous steps, data should start flowing to the customer storage account based on the configuration in the XML file.
trans-unit.target: About five minutes after you complete the previous steps, data should start flowing to the customer storage account based on the configuration in the XML file.

trans-unit.source: There are many tools available to view data from Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: There are many tools available to view data from Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see:
trans-unit.target: For more information, see:

trans-unit.source: Browsing Storage Resources with Server Explorer
trans-unit.target: Browsing Storage Resources with Server Explorer

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage Explorer 6 Preview 3 (August 2014)
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage Explorer 6 Preview 3 (August 2014)

trans-unit.source: To view your data:
trans-unit.target: To view your data:

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio (2013, 2012 and 2010 with SP1), click **View**, and then click **Server Explorer**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio (2013, 2012 and 2010 with SP1), click **View**, and then click **Server Explorer**.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the storage account.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the storage account.

trans-unit.source: Click **Tables** and then double-click the appropriate tables to view the security logs collected from the virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: Click **Tables** and then double-click the appropriate tables to view the security logs collected from the virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the table named WADWindowsEventLogsTable, then click **View Data** to open the table view as shown here:
trans-unit.target: Right-click the table named WADWindowsEventLogsTable, then click **View Data** to open the table view as shown here:

trans-unit.source: In the previous storage table, **PartitionKey**, **RowKey**, and **Timestamp** are system properties.
trans-unit.target: In the previous storage table, **PartitionKey**, **RowKey**, and **Timestamp** are system properties.

trans-unit.source: **PartitionKey** is a time stamp in seconds, and it is a unique identifier for the partition within the table.
trans-unit.target: **PartitionKey** is a time stamp in seconds, and it is a unique identifier for the partition within the table.

trans-unit.source: **RowKey** is a unique identifier for an entity within a partition.
trans-unit.target: **RowKey** is a unique identifier for an entity within a partition.

trans-unit.source: Together, **PartitionKey** and **RowKey** uniquely identify every entity within a table.
trans-unit.target: Together, **PartitionKey** and **RowKey** uniquely identify every entity within a table.

trans-unit.source: Timestamp is a date/time value that is maintained on the server to track when an entity was last modified.
trans-unit.target: Timestamp is a date/time value that is maintained on the server to track when an entity was last modified.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The maximum row size in an Azure Storage table is limited to 1 MB.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The maximum row size in an Azure Storage table is limited to 1 MB.

trans-unit.source: A storage account can contain up to 200 TB of data from blobs, queues, and tables if the account was created after June 2012.
trans-unit.target: A storage account can contain up to 200 TB of data from blobs, queues, and tables if the account was created after June 2012.

trans-unit.source: Thus, your table size can grow up to 200 TB if blobs and queues do not take any storage space.
trans-unit.target: Thus, your table size can grow up to 200 TB if blobs and queues do not take any storage space.

trans-unit.source: Accounts created before June 2012 have a limit of 100 TB.
trans-unit.target: Accounts created before June 2012 have a limit of 100 TB.

trans-unit.source: Storage Explorer also gives you the option to edit table data.
trans-unit.target: Storage Explorer also gives you the option to edit table data.

trans-unit.source: Double-click a particular row in the Table view to open the Edit Entity window as shown here:
trans-unit.target: Double-click a particular row in the Table view to open the Edit Entity window as shown here:

trans-unit.source: Update an existing security log collection pipeline with a new configuration on a virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Update an existing security log collection pipeline with a new configuration on a virtual machine

trans-unit.source: In this section, we update an existing Azure Diagnostics security log collection pipeline on a virtual machine, and we detect Windows application event log errors.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we update an existing Azure Diagnostics security log collection pipeline on a virtual machine, and we detect Windows application event log errors.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Update configuration file to include events of interest
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Update configuration file to include events of interest

trans-unit.source: The Azure Diagnostics file created in the previous example needs to be updated to include Windows application event log error types.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Diagnostics file created in the previous example needs to be updated to include Windows application event log error types.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Any existing Azure Diagnostics configuration settings need to be merged with the new configuration file.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Any existing Azure Diagnostics configuration settings need to be merged with the new configuration file.

trans-unit.source: The settings defined in the new file will overwrite the existing configurations.
trans-unit.target: The settings defined in the new file will overwrite the existing configurations.

trans-unit.source: To retrieve the existing configuration setting, you can use the **Get-AzureVMDiagnosticsExtension** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To retrieve the existing configuration setting, you can use the **Get-AzureVMDiagnosticsExtension** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The following is a sample Azure PowerShell script to retrieve the existing configuration:
trans-unit.target: The following is a sample Azure PowerShell script to retrieve the existing configuration:

trans-unit.source: Update the Azure Diagnostics configuration to collect Windows application event log errors and critical events as follows:
trans-unit.target: Update the Azure Diagnostics configuration to collect Windows application event log errors and critical events as follows:

trans-unit.source: Validate the configuration file by using the same steps as shown earlier in [Step 3: Validate configuration XML file](#step3).
trans-unit.target: Validate the configuration file by using the same steps as shown earlier in [Step 3: Validate configuration XML file](#step3).

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Update Azure Diagnostics to use new configuration file
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Update Azure Diagnostics to use new configuration file

trans-unit.source: Use the **Set-AzureVMDiagnosticsExtension** and **Update-AzureVM** cmdlets to update the configuration as shown earlier in [Step 4: Configure Azure Diagnostics](#step4).
trans-unit.target: Use the **Set-AzureVMDiagnosticsExtension** and **Update-AzureVM** cmdlets to update the configuration as shown earlier in [Step 4: Configure Azure Diagnostics](#step4).

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Verify configuration settings
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Verify configuration settings

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to verify that the configuration settings have been updated:
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to verify that the configuration settings have been updated:

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Generate events
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Generate events

trans-unit.source: For this example, run the following command to generate an application event log of the type **Error**:
trans-unit.target: For this example, run the following command to generate an application event log of the type **Error**:

trans-unit.source: Open the Event viewer to verify that event is created.
trans-unit.target: Open the Event viewer to verify that event is created.

trans-unit.source: Step 5: View data
trans-unit.target: Step 5: View data

trans-unit.source: Open Server Explorer in Visual Studio to view the log data.
trans-unit.target: Open Server Explorer in Visual Studio to view the log data.

trans-unit.target: You should see an **EventID 100** created on **ContosoDesktop** as shown here:

trans-unit.target: Security data collection from Azure Cloud Services by using Azure Diagnostics

trans-unit.target: We will now use Azure Diagnostics to explore the same two log collection scenarios from Azure Cloud Services as in the previous Virtual Machines (IaaS) section:

trans-unit.target: Update an existing log collection pipeline in a cloud service:

trans-unit.target: Enable auditing of host firewall events (as an example of network security events) by using Auditpol

trans-unit.source: All of the events and logs are collected into a customer storage account in Azure.
trans-unit.target: All of the events and logs are collected into a customer storage account in Azure.

trans-unit.source: The events can be viewed and exported by the customer to on-premises SIEM systems.
trans-unit.target: The events can be viewed and exported by the customer to on-premises SIEM systems.

trans-unit.source: They can also be aggregated and analyzed by using HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: They can also be aggregated and analyzed by using HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: Set up a new instance of a log collection pipeline on a cloud service
trans-unit.target: Set up a new instance of a log collection pipeline on a cloud service

trans-unit.source: In this example, we set up a new instance of a security log collection pipeline that uses Azure Diagnostics, and we detect user addition to a local group, and new process creation events on a cloud service instance.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we set up a new instance of a security log collection pipeline that uses Azure Diagnostics, and we detect user addition to a local group, and new process creation events on a cloud service instance.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Create a cloud service (web role) and deploy
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Create a cloud service (web role) and deploy

trans-unit.source: On your development computer, launch Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: On your development computer, launch Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: Create a new cloud service project (our example uses ContosoWebRole).
trans-unit.target: Create a new cloud service project (our example uses ContosoWebRole).

trans-unit.source: Select the **ASP.NET** web role.
trans-unit.target: Select the **ASP.NET** web role.

trans-unit.source: Select the **MVC** project.
trans-unit.target: Select the **MVC** project.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, click **Roles**, then double-click the web role (WebRole1) to open the **Properties** window.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, click **Roles**, then double-click the web role (WebRole1) to open the **Properties** window.

trans-unit.source: On the **Configuration** tab, clear the **Enable Diagnostics** check box to disable the version of Azure Diagnostics that ships with Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: On the **Configuration** tab, clear the **Enable Diagnostics** check box to disable the version of Azure Diagnostics that ships with Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: Build your solution to verify that you have no errors.
trans-unit.target: Build your solution to verify that you have no errors.

trans-unit.source: Open the file WebRole1/Controllers/HomeController.cs.
trans-unit.target: Open the file WebRole1/Controllers/HomeController.cs.

trans-unit.source: Add the following method to enable the sample application to log HTTP status code 500 as a sample IIS log event (this will be used in the IIS example later):
trans-unit.target: Add the following method to enable the sample application to log HTTP status code 500 as a sample IIS log event (this will be used in the IIS example later):

trans-unit.source: Right-click the name of the cloud service project, and click **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the name of the cloud service project, and click **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Prepare the configuration file
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Prepare the configuration file

trans-unit.source: We will now prepare the Azure Diagnostics configuration file to add the events that can help detect the following situations:
trans-unit.target: We will now prepare the Azure Diagnostics configuration file to add the events that can help detect the following situations:

trans-unit.target: New user addition to a local group

trans-unit.target: New process creation

trans-unit.target: Step 3: Validate configuration XML file

trans-unit.target: Validate the configuration file by using the same steps as shown earlier in [Step 3: Validate configuration XML file](#step3).

trans-unit.target: Step 4: Configure Azure Diagnostics

trans-unit.target: Run the following Azure PowerShell script to enable Azure Diagnostics (make sure to update the storage_name, key, config_path, and service_name).

trans-unit.target: To verify that your service has the latest diagnostic configuration, run the following Azure PowerShell command:

trans-unit.target: Step 5: Generate events

trans-unit.source: To generate events:
trans-unit.target: To generate events:

trans-unit.target: To start a Remote Desktop session to your cloud service instance, in Visual Studio, open Server Explorer, right-click the role instance, and click Connect using Remote Desktop.

trans-unit.source: Open an elevated command prompt and run the following commands to create a local administrator account on the virtual machine:
trans-unit.target: Open an elevated command prompt and run the following commands to create a local administrator account on the virtual machine:

trans-unit.target: Open Event Viewer, open the **Security** channel, and notice that an Event 4732 has been created, as shown here:

trans-unit.target: Step 6: View data

trans-unit.target: Wait about five minutes to allow the Azure Diagnostics agent to push events to the storage table.

trans-unit.source: To validate the Process Creation event, open a Notepad.
trans-unit.target: To validate the Process Creation event, open a Notepad.

trans-unit.source: Update an existing log collection pipeline in a cloud service with a new configuration
trans-unit.target: Update an existing log collection pipeline in a cloud service with a new configuration

trans-unit.source: In this section, we update an existing Azure Diagnostics security log collection pipeline, and detect Windows Firewall Change Events in a Cloud Service instance.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we update an existing Azure Diagnostics security log collection pipeline, and detect Windows Firewall Change Events in a Cloud Service instance.

trans-unit.source: To detect firewall changes, we will update the existing configuration to include firewall change events.
trans-unit.target: To detect firewall changes, we will update the existing configuration to include firewall change events.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Get existing configuration
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Get existing configuration

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The new configuration settings will overwrite the existing configuration.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The new configuration settings will overwrite the existing configuration.

trans-unit.source: Thus, it is important that any existing Azure Diagnostics configuration settings be merged with the new configuration file.
trans-unit.target: Thus, it is important that any existing Azure Diagnostics configuration settings be merged with the new configuration file.

trans-unit.source: To retrieve the existing configuration setting, you can use the **Get-AzureServiceDiagnosticsExtension** cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: To retrieve the existing configuration setting, you can use the **Get-AzureServiceDiagnosticsExtension** cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Update configuration XML to include firewall events
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Update configuration XML to include firewall events

trans-unit.source: Validate the XML contents by using the same validation process as described earlier in [Step 3: Validate configuration XML file](#step3).
trans-unit.target: Validate the XML contents by using the same validation process as described earlier in [Step 3: Validate configuration XML file](#step3).

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Update Azure Diagnostics to use new configuration
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Update Azure Diagnostics to use new configuration

trans-unit.source: Run the following Azure PowerShell script to update Azure Diagnostics to use the new configuration (make sure to update the storage_name, key, config_path, and service_name with your cloud service information).
trans-unit.target: Run the following Azure PowerShell script to update Azure Diagnostics to use the new configuration (make sure to update the storage_name, key, config_path, and service_name with your cloud service information).

trans-unit.source: To verify that your service has the latest diagnostic configuration, run the following Azure PowerShell command:
trans-unit.target: To verify that your service has the latest diagnostic configuration, run the following Azure PowerShell command:

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Enable firewall events
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Enable firewall events

trans-unit.source: Open a Remote Desktop session to your cloud service instance.
trans-unit.target: Open a Remote Desktop session to your cloud service instance.

trans-unit.source: Open an elevated command prompt and run the following command:
trans-unit.target: Open an elevated command prompt and run the following command:

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Generate events
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Generate events

trans-unit.source: Open Windows Firewall, and click **Inbound Rules**.
trans-unit.target: Open Windows Firewall, and click **Inbound Rules**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Add New Rule**, and then click **Port**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Add New Rule**, and then click **Port**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Local Ports** field, type **5000**, and then click **Next** three times.
trans-unit.target: In the **Local Ports** field, type **5000**, and then click **Next** three times.

trans-unit.source: In the **Name** field, type **Test5000**, and then click **Finish**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Name** field, type **Test5000**, and then click **Finish**.

trans-unit.source: Open Event Viewer, open the **Security** channel, and notice that an Event ID 4946 has been created as shown here:
trans-unit.target: Open Event Viewer, open the **Security** channel, and notice that an Event ID 4946 has been created as shown here:

trans-unit.source: Step 6: View data
trans-unit.target: Step 6: View data

trans-unit.source: Wait about five minutes to allow the Azure Diagnostics agent to push the event data to the storage table.
trans-unit.target: Wait about five minutes to allow the Azure Diagnostics agent to push the event data to the storage table.

trans-unit.source: Security event distribution and spike detection
trans-unit.target: Security event distribution and spike detection

trans-unit.source: After the events are in the customer’s storage account, applications can use the storage client libraries to access and perform event aggregation.
trans-unit.target: After the events are in the customer’s storage account, applications can use the storage client libraries to access and perform event aggregation.

trans-unit.source: For sample code to access table data, see [How to: Retrieve table data](storage-dotnet-how-to-use-tables.md).
trans-unit.target: For sample code to access table data, see [How to: Retrieve table data](storage-dotnet-how-to-use-tables.md).

trans-unit.source: Following is an example of event aggregation.
trans-unit.target: Following is an example of event aggregation.

trans-unit.source: Any spikes in event distribution can be investigated further for anomalous activity.
trans-unit.target: Any spikes in event distribution can be investigated further for anomalous activity.

trans-unit.source: IIS log collection and processing by using HDInsight
trans-unit.target: IIS log collection and processing by using HDInsight

trans-unit.source: In this section, we collect IIS logs from your web role instance and move the logs to an Azure blob in the customer’s storage account.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we collect IIS logs from your web role instance and move the logs to an Azure blob in the customer’s storage account.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Update configuration file to include IIS log collection
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Update configuration file to include IIS log collection

trans-unit.source: In the previous Azure Diagnostics configuration, **containerName** is the blob container name to which logs will be moved within customer’s storage account.
trans-unit.target: In the previous Azure Diagnostics configuration, **containerName** is the blob container name to which logs will be moved within customer’s storage account.

trans-unit.source: Validate the configuration file by using the same steps as shown earlier in [Step 3: Validate configuration XML file](#step3).
trans-unit.target: Validate the configuration file by using the same steps as shown earlier in [Step 3: Validate configuration XML file](#step3).

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Update Azure Diagnostics to use a new configuration
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Update Azure Diagnostics to use a new configuration

trans-unit.source: Run the following Azure PowerShell script to update Azure Diagnostics to use the new configuration (make sure to update the storage_name, key, config_path, and service_name with your cloud service information).
trans-unit.target: Run the following Azure PowerShell script to update Azure Diagnostics to use the new configuration (make sure to update the storage_name, key, config_path, and service_name with your cloud service information).

trans-unit.source: To verify that your service has the latest diagnostic configuration, run the following Azure PowerShell command:
trans-unit.target: To verify that your service has the latest diagnostic configuration, run the following Azure PowerShell command:

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Generate IIS logs
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Generate IIS logs

trans-unit.source: Open a web browser and navigate to the cloud service web role (for example, http://contosowebrole.cloudapp.net/).
trans-unit.target: Open a web browser and navigate to the cloud service web role (for example, http://contosowebrole.cloudapp.net/).

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the **About** and **Contact** pages to create some log events.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the **About** and **Contact** pages to create some log events.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to a page that generates a status code 500 (for example, http://contosowebrole.cloudapp.net/Home/StatusCode500).
trans-unit.target: Navigate to a page that generates a status code 500 (for example, http://contosowebrole.cloudapp.net/Home/StatusCode500).

trans-unit.source: You should see an error such as the one that follows.
trans-unit.target: You should see an error such as the one that follows.

trans-unit.source: Remember that we added code for **StatusCode500** in Step 1 of section titled Set up new instance of log collection pipeline on a cloud ServiceName.
trans-unit.target: Remember that we added code for **StatusCode500** in Step 1 of section titled Set up new instance of log collection pipeline on a cloud ServiceName.

trans-unit.source: Open a Remote Desktop session to your cloud service instance.
trans-unit.target: Open a Remote Desktop session to your cloud service instance.

trans-unit.source: Open IIS Manager.
trans-unit.target: Open IIS Manager.

trans-unit.source: IIS Logging is enabled by default and it is set to hourly generate files that contain all fields in W3C format.
trans-unit.target: IIS Logging is enabled by default and it is set to hourly generate files that contain all fields in W3C format.

trans-unit.source: Click **Browse**, and there will be at least one log file, as shown here:
trans-unit.target: Click **Browse**, and there will be at least one log file, as shown here:

trans-unit.source: Wait for about five minutes for the Azure Diagnostics agent to push the log file to the blob container.
trans-unit.target: Wait for about five minutes for the Azure Diagnostics agent to push the log file to the blob container.

trans-unit.source: To validate the data, open **Server Explorer** > **Storage** > **Storage Account** > **Blobs**.
trans-unit.target: To validate the data, open **Server Explorer** > **Storage** > **Storage Account** > **Blobs**.

trans-unit.source: As shown here, the blob **iislogs** is created:
trans-unit.target: As shown here, the blob **iislogs** is created:

trans-unit.source: Right-click and select **View Blob Container** to display the IIS log file stored in the blob:
trans-unit.target: Right-click and select **View Blob Container** to display the IIS log file stored in the blob:

trans-unit.source: After the IIS events are in the customer’s storage account, applications that leverage HDInsight analysis can be used to perform event aggregation.
trans-unit.target: After the IIS events are in the customer’s storage account, applications that leverage HDInsight analysis can be used to perform event aggregation.

trans-unit.source: The following line chart is an example of an event aggregation task that shows HTTP Status Code 500:
trans-unit.target: The following line chart is an example of an event aggregation task that shows HTTP Status Code 500:

trans-unit.source: Security log collection recommendations
trans-unit.target: Security log collection recommendations

trans-unit.source: When you are collecting security logs, we recommend that you:
trans-unit.target: When you are collecting security logs, we recommend that you:

trans-unit.source: Collect your own service application-specific audit log events.
trans-unit.target: Collect your own service application-specific audit log events.

trans-unit.source: Configure only the data that you need for analysis and monitoring.
trans-unit.target: Configure only the data that you need for analysis and monitoring.

trans-unit.source: Capturing too much data can make it harder to troubleshoot and can impact your service or storage costs.
trans-unit.target: Capturing too much data can make it harder to troubleshoot and can impact your service or storage costs.

trans-unit.source: Merge existing Azure Diagnostics configuration settings with changes you make.
trans-unit.target: Merge existing Azure Diagnostics configuration settings with changes you make.

trans-unit.source: The new configuration file overwrites the existing configuration settings.
trans-unit.target: The new configuration file overwrites the existing configuration settings.

trans-unit.source: Choose the **Scheduled Transfer Period** interval wisely.
trans-unit.target: Choose the **Scheduled Transfer Period** interval wisely.

trans-unit.source: Shorter transfer times will increase data relevance, but that can increase storage costs and processing overhead.
trans-unit.target: Shorter transfer times will increase data relevance, but that can increase storage costs and processing overhead.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The other variable that will significantly impact the amount of data collected is the logging level.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The other variable that will significantly impact the amount of data collected is the logging level.

trans-unit.source: The following is an example of how to filter logs by logging level:
trans-unit.target: The following is an example of how to filter logs by logging level:

trans-unit.source: The logging level is cumulative.
trans-unit.target: The logging level is cumulative.

trans-unit.source: If the filter is set to **Warning**, then **Error** and **Critical** events will also be collected.
trans-unit.target: If the filter is set to **Warning**, then **Error** and **Critical** events will also be collected.

trans-unit.source: Periodically clear the diagnostic data from Azure Storage if it is no longer needed.
trans-unit.target: Periodically clear the diagnostic data from Azure Storage if it is no longer needed.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] To learn more about diagnostic data see [Store and View Diagnostic Data in Azure Storage](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/hh411534.aspx).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] To learn more about diagnostic data see [Store and View Diagnostic Data in Azure Storage](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/hh411534.aspx).

trans-unit.source: The containers and tables that store diagnostic data are just like other containers and tables, you can delete blobs and entities from them in the same way you would for other data.
trans-unit.target: The containers and tables that store diagnostic data are just like other containers and tables, you can delete blobs and entities from them in the same way you would for other data.

trans-unit.source: You can delete the diagnostic data programmatically via one of the storage client libraries or visually via a [storage explorer client](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/windowsazurestorage/archive/2014/03/11/windows-azure-storage-explorers-2014.aspx).
trans-unit.target: You can delete the diagnostic data programmatically via one of the storage client libraries or visually via a [storage explorer client](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/windowsazurestorage/archive/2014/03/11/windows-azure-storage-explorers-2014.aspx).

trans-unit.source: It is a best practice to store service data and security log data in separate storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: It is a best practice to store service data and security log data in separate storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: This isolation ensures that saving security log data does not impact the storage performance for production service data.
trans-unit.target: This isolation ensures that saving security log data does not impact the storage performance for production service data.

trans-unit.source: Choose the log retention duration based on your organization’s compliance policy and data analysis and monitoring requirements.
trans-unit.target: Choose the log retention duration based on your organization’s compliance policy and data analysis and monitoring requirements.

trans-unit.source: Exporting security logs to another system
trans-unit.target: Exporting security logs to another system

trans-unit.source: You can download blob data by using the Azure Storage Client Library, and then export it to your on-premises system for processing.
trans-unit.target: You can download blob data by using the Azure Storage Client Library, and then export it to your on-premises system for processing.

trans-unit.source: For sample code to manage blob data, see [How to use Blob Storage from .NET](storage-dotnet-how-to-use-blobs.md).
trans-unit.target: For sample code to manage blob data, see [How to use Blob Storage from .NET](storage-dotnet-how-to-use-blobs.md).

trans-unit.source: Similarly, you can download security data stored in Azure tables by using the Azure Storage Client Library.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, you can download security data stored in Azure tables by using the Azure Storage Client Library.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about accessing data that is stored in tables, see [How to use Table Storage from .NET](storage-dotnet-how-to-use-tables.md).
trans-unit.target: To learn more about accessing data that is stored in tables, see [How to use Table Storage from .NET](storage-dotnet-how-to-use-tables.md).

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory reports
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory reports

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) includes a set of security, usage, and audit log reports that provide visibility into the integrity and security of your Azure AD tenant.
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) includes a set of security, usage, and audit log reports that provide visibility into the integrity and security of your Azure AD tenant.

trans-unit.source: For example, Azure AD has the capability to automatically analyze user activity and surface anomalous access, and then make it available through customer-visible reports.
trans-unit.target: For example, Azure AD has the capability to automatically analyze user activity and surface anomalous access, and then make it available through customer-visible reports.

trans-unit.source: These reports are available through the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com/) under **Active Directory** > **Directory**.
trans-unit.target: These reports are available through the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com/) under **Active Directory** > **Directory**.

trans-unit.source: Some of these reports are free, and others are offered as part of an Azure AD Premium edition.
trans-unit.target: Some of these reports are free, and others are offered as part of an Azure AD Premium edition.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Azure AD reports, see [View your access and usage reports](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn283934.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about Azure AD reports, see [View your access and usage reports](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn283934.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Azure Operation Logs
trans-unit.target: Azure Operation Logs

trans-unit.source: Logs for operations related to your Azure subscription resources are also available through the **Operation Logs** feature in the management portal.
trans-unit.target: Logs for operations related to your Azure subscription resources are also available through the **Operation Logs** feature in the management portal.

trans-unit.source: To view the **Operation Logs**, open the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com/), click **Management Services**, and then click **Operation Logs**.
trans-unit.target: To view the **Operation Logs**, open the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com/), click **Management Services**, and then click **Operation Logs**.
